{"code":1,"isDone":false,"toInsertArticleList":[{"createdTime":"2021-04-10 11:45:31","updatedTime":"2021-04-10 11:45:31","title":"SCOTT GALLOWAY: The crypto industry is a $2 trillion disruptive force, and its success boils down to two main attributes","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/scott-galloway-scarcity-reason-crypto-industry-successful-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6070a0144943790018bb1b2d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"5,000 everydays artwork by Beeple, which was sold at Christies auction house for $69 million\" height=\"3000\" width=\"4000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The &#39;Everydays: the First 5000 Days&#39; digital artwork by Beeple, which sold at Christies auction house for $69 million.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Scott Galloway is a bestselling author and professor of marketing at NYU Stern.</li>\n<li>The following is a recent blog post, republished with permission, that originally ran on his blog, &#34;No Mercy / No Malice.&#34;</li>\n<li>In it, Galloway explains how scarcity is the driving force behind the crypto industry&#39;s success.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Any firm that approaches $1 trillion in value has tapped into a basic human instinct. Consuming, signalling, loving, and praying have been the fuel of Amazon, Apple, Facebook, and Google&#39;s ascents, respectively. That the crypto asset class universe has <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/04/06/cryptocurrency-market-cap-tops-2-trillion-for-the-first-time.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">reached $2 trillion</a> reveals, I believe, that it taps into two attributes we instinctively pursue: trust and scarcity.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60709dd1a451820019b3a557?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Scott Galloway\" height=\"678\" width=\"1560\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.profgalloway.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Scott Galloway</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2>Trust</h2><p>Our superpower as a species is cooperation, which requires trust. It&#39;s the reason banks, traffic lights, and anesthesiologists exist. Even before crypto, creative minds have been drawn to finance, as trust creates opportunities for leverage and securitization. In 1997, seeking more control over his songwriting catalog, David Bowie raised $55 million with Bowie Bonds. The bonds paid 7.9% interest over a 10 year-long term - a scant premium to a US 10 Year Treasury Note at 6.45%. What made Bowie Bonds unique was the collateral, or source of trust: future royalties on Bowie&#39;s music, which the bondholder felt people would continue to value. Moody&#39;s rated the bonds A3 and Bowie used the proceeds to buy out his former manager, shoring up the bonds and securing long-term control of his music.</p><p>Though innovative in its collateralization, the Bowie Bond was on its face a vanilla financial instrument, no different in form than a bond issued by GM or P&#38;G. In order to connect his art and potential investors, Bowie had to rely on the (expensive) apparatus of traditional gatekeepers in finance and entertainment to imbue his bonds with the essential attributes of trust and scarcity. The royalty stream (trust) was mediated by lawyers and accountants in big publishing houses, and the legitimacy of each individual bond (scarcity) was dependent on the financial powers of Wall Street.</p><p>What if Sir David Bowie (note: he declined knighthood in 2003, but it&#39;s my blog) fell to earth in 2021? What might Bowie have done … with crypto?</p><h2>Scarcity</h2><p>People like scarcity - a lot. Owning something scarce makes one feel unique, and signals success and worthiness as a potential mate. Scarcity is also an instinctual trigger for obsession - when we sense a scarcity of something, be it food or a mate, we are programmed to become obsessed with finding it. Art auctions, the (pre-pandemic) lines outside Supreme, and the margins on a Panerai Tourbillon prove this point.</p><p>A Van Gogh and a Rothko are both unique, and therefore scarce, because they are made of atoms, and it is impossible to arrange a second set of atoms in an identical configuration. Print artists, whose lithographs are made to be reproduced without alteration, use a small &#34;17/100&#34; written in the corner, to distinguish each print and bestow scarcity upon it.</p><p>To hold value, scarcity must be credible. The dirty (not-so) secret of the art world is that art buyers, and even professional art appraisers, <a href=\"https://time.com/4236970/a-fake-rothko-and-the-rise-of-modern-fraud/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">struggle to discern</a> originals from forgeries. A well-made forgery provides the same practical value as an original - you can hang it on your wall and bask in its profundity. Yet the art world invests millions of dollars in identifying the &#34;real&#34; version of valuable works; once unmasked, forgeries are nearly worthless.</p><p>Digital art suffers from perfect reproducibility, and hence, a lack of scarcity. There is no &#34;real&#34; version - even in the artist&#39;s studio, copies proliferate in backups, on shared drives, and in cache files. For decades, we have experimented with watermarks and anti-piracy tech to try and enforce a physical, world-of-atoms scarcity on digital goods. By contrast, non-fungible tokens, (NFTs) reflect a digital-native approach to credible scarcity.</p><p><strong>Attaching an NFT to a digital artwork gives the NFT owner discretion to designate any digital copy of that artwork as the sole authentic copy at any point in time. </strong>This approach jettisons our world-of-atoms obsession with a specific physical object, and acknowledges that scarcity has always been a function of bits, not atoms. Value is in the eye of the beholder.</p><h2>Let&#39;s dance</h2><p>On March 11, digital artist Beeple collected $69.3 million (minus the hefty fee of his gatekeeper, Christie&#39;s) from the auction of an NFT associated with a collage of his 13 year-long project of daily digital artworks. The media has made much of the fact that the buyer of Beeple&#39;s NFT, crypto investor Vignesh Sundaresan, did not obtain any tangible &#34;thing&#34; for his money. The art itself is available for anyone to view - for free - on <a href=\"https://www.beeple-crap.com/everydays\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Beeple&#39;s web site</a>. But collecting art has rarely been about the thing. It&#39;s about credible scarcity.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60709e04a451820019b3a559?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Scott Galloway\" height=\"678\" width=\"1560\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.profgalloway.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Scott Galloway</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>NFTs create and capture the value of scarcity cred in a massively dispersed fashion that bypasses gatekeepers and taps into capital anywhere. At the high end, digital art sold for millions doesn&#39;t really need an NFT, just as Bowie didn&#39;t need crypto to securitize his royalties in 1997. Christie&#39;s could have just as easily sold an embossed paper certificate, and entered the buyer&#39;s name in a leather bound book securely held at Christie&#39;s headquarters. But that sort of infrastructure isn&#39;t available to the vast majority of digital artists, whereas anyone can create an NFT. <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/22/business/nft-nba-top-shot-crypto.html?smid=url-share\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Nyan Cat</a>, a pop culture meme, isn&#39;t likely to appear at Christie&#39;s any time soon, but as an NFT it sold for nearly $600,000.</p><h2>All the young dudes</h2><p>Scarcity cred explains more than NFTs. The entire $2 trillion crypto asset class rests on scarcity cred. Bitcoin&#39;s attractiveness as a store of value is a function of its scarcity cred, as it has a built-in limit of 21 million coins. Compare that to the USD: Almost 30% of the US money supply has been created since 2020.</p><p>There&#39;s a variety of crypto technologies/products/platforms evolving new means of creating and capturing value in a network: Ethereum, Ledger, Uniswap, Hedera, Cardano - a soup of innovation that is, similar to other tech innovations, not doing anything new … just doing it better.</p><p>It remains to be seen if this approach will take hold. Crypto&#39;s energy use is a source of real concern, but the hardware and software are evolving quickly to become far more energy efficient. Even Beeple thinks the current mania is a bubble, as he told my podcasting partner Kara Swisher. But the history of the art market is a history of bubbles, as are the histories of finance and the internet. All are still with us.</p><p>Crypto is firing on the walls of the world&#39;s financial citadels. Naturally, the generation of leaders behind those walls is not inclined to acknowledge the Wildlings outside. But scoffing at novel technology, be it a mangonel, black powder, or blockchain, rarely ends well for the legacy asset holders. Bigger castles are already being erected on the hill just above the naysayers … in this case, in mere years vs. generations. It&#39;s likely that on the day of its imminent public listing, Coinbase will be more valuable than Goldman Sachs. A reasonable question in the JPMorgan and Goldman board meetings:</p><p><em>How the fuck did we/you let Coinbase happen?</em></p><p>But that&#39;s another post. Unencumbered by regulation, reticence to destroy legacy assets, or boomer brains that just don&#39;t &#34;get it,&#34; crypto is a $2 trillion disruptive force. I can validate that anybody over 50 has trouble understanding this stuff, and am fairly certain that the number of candles on the CEO&#39;s office party birthday cake is inversely correlated to their understanding of crypto.</p><p>Of course, in a system that is still heavily skewed in favor of older, white men, &#34;getting it&#34; for that cohort can be worth billions. Crypto investors Michael Novogratz and Michael Saylor, both over 50, have a combined net worth approaching $10 billion. <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/johnhyatt/2021/04/06/the-cryptocurrency-tycoons-on-forbes-2021-billionaires-list/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">But they are the exceptions</a>.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60709e32a451820019b3a55e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Scott Galloway\" height=\"260\" width=\"520\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.profgalloway.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Scott Galloway</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Bowie himself was 50 when he issued Bowie Bonds. A prolific <a href=\"https://www.sothebys.com/en/slideshows/inside-david-bowies-private-collection\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">art collector</a>, Bowie was also famous for <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/13/arts/music/all-the-young-bands-the-artists-david-bowie-championed.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">championing</a> young creators, and being enamored of technology: In 1998, he launched his own internet service provider, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/jan/11/david-bowie-bowienet-isp-internet\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">BowieNet</a>, an interactive music community a decade ahead of its time, and the next year, he launched an online bank (BowieBanc). &#34;If I was 19 again, I&#39;d bypass music and go right to the internet,&#34; he said at the time. In a prescient 1999 <a href=\"https://youtu.be/LaHcOs7mhfU\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">interview</a>, he is a time traveler explaining the future to our skeptical past.</p><p>RIP Bowie, you would have loved crypto.</p><p>Life is so rich,</p><p>Scott</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a id=\"table-of-contents-sticky\" class=\"mceNonEditable\" data-type=\"h2\">\n Table of Contents: Masthead Sticky\n</bi-shortcode>The Wusthof set is our top pick because it comes with every knife you need for most tasks, a honing steel, and shears.\n<ul class=\"summary-list\">\n <li>A good, reliable set of knives is essential to any kitchen.</li>\n <li>We consulted metallurgists, chefs, and butcher Pat LaFrieda to find the best knife sets out there. </li>\n <li>The Wusthof set is our top pick because it comes with every knife you need for most tasks, a honing steel, and shears.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>Whether you're prepping go-to recipes in your home kitchen or working on the line at the latest Michelin-starred restaurant, having good knives is essential. But you don't need many: Between a chef's knife and a paring knife, you can chop, slice, dice, cube, mince, brunoise, chiffonade, julienne, and more. Beyond those two, you'll probably want a bread knife, and depending on how much meat and poultry you cook, you may consider a boning or utility knife as well. Tracking down the perfect kitchen knives individually might be preferred depending on whom you ask, but it can also be a time-consuming and expensive task, which is why purchasing them as a set is often a practical choice. </p>\n<p>I've done stints in restaurants and raw bars, served as a galley cook aboard a private yacht, and filleted and shucked more seafood while working on fishing boats than I can recount. For this guide, I tested eleven knife sets, focusing on balance between the blades and handles, quality of construction, and edge retention.</p>\n<p>While sharpness was a given (any knife not sharp out of the package would've been immediately disqualified), we chose to test edge retention by slicing tomatoes before running knives on a glass cutting board 200 times in order to dull them (pro tip: for the sake of your knives, never use a glass cutting board). After dulling, we tried slicing tomatoes again to determine which edges held up best. We also consulted a professor of metallurgy to provide insight into the pros and cons of different alloys, and to break down our contenders' hardness ratings. </p>\n<p>Below are the knife sets that passed our tests exceptionally well. You can learn more about our methodology <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-knife-set#methodology-5\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">here</a>, and if you're still unsure as to whether a pre-assembled knife kit will suit your needs, check out <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-knife-set#why-you-may-want-to-put-your-knife-set-together-piecemeal-8\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">our list</a> of the pros and cons of buying your knives piecemeal.</p>\n<h2>Here are the best knife sets in 2021</h2>\n<ul class=\"summary-list\">\n <li><strong>Best knife set overall: <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004U8QD9K/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&amp;tag=biipgf_092319_best-kitchen-knives-20&amp;camp=1789&amp;creative=9325&amp;linkCode=as2&amp;creativeASIN=B004U8QD9K&amp;linkId=df4280e6961992e84da48e7cc673d65a961992e84da48e7cc673d65a\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener nofollow nofollow nofollow sponsored nofollow sponsored nofollow sponsored nofollow sponsored nofollow sponsored\">Wusthof Classic Ikon 7-Piece</a></strong></li>\n <li>Best knife set on a budget: <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004IEBTZ4/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&amp;tag=biipgf_121317_best-knife-sets-20&amp;camp=1789&amp;creative=9325&amp;linkCode=as2&amp;creativeASIN=B004IEBTZ4&amp;linkId=b1f1ed3ad86ad577bb7d56a0ab528ba6d86ad577bb7d56a0ab528ba6\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Victorinox Fibrox Pro 4-piece</a></li>\n <li>Best knife set upgrade: <a href=\"https://go.skimresources.com?id=35871X943606&amp;xs=1&amp;url=https%3A%2F%2Ffnsharp.com%2Fknife-collections%2F3-knife-set%2Fe-set%2F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow nofollow noopener sponsored sponsored\">F.N. Sharp</a></li>\n <li>Best knife set with a sharpening subscription: <a href=\"https://knifey.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Knifey</a></li>\n</ul>\n<aside class=\"quick-tip headline-regular\">\n <p><strong>Updated on 04/09/2021: </strong>We rewrote this guide after speaking with experts and testing eleven knife sets. We're continuing to look for more specialized options, including the best Japanese set. We've just tested two from <a href=\"https://shun.kaiusa.com/knife-sets.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Shun</a>, which we love so far (and recommend below), and we are currently considering knife sets from <a href=\"https://www.korin.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Korin</a> and <a href=\"https://www.globalcutleryusa.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Global</a>. </p>\n</aside> \n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n  The best knife set overall \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/603022f8623bd30012bcc4d6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Wusthof knife set\" height=\"900\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Owen Burke/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> \n <h3><a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004U8QD9K/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&amp;tag=biipgf_092319_best-kitchen-knives-20&amp;camp=1789&amp;creative=9325&amp;linkCode=as2&amp;creativeASIN=B004U8QD9K&amp;linkId=df4280e6961992e84da48e7cc673d65a\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Wusthof's Classic Ikon 7-Piece Knife Block Set</a> includes four well-balanced, durable, easy-to-grip knives, as well as a honing steel, kitchen shears, and a solid walnut block.&nbsp;</h3>\n <p><strong>Pros: </strong>Great weight and balance, impressive edge retention</p>\n <p><strong>Cons: </strong>Wood block is on the larger side, bread knife could be longer</p>\n <aside class=\"breakout-box headline-regular\">\n  <ul>\n   <li><strong>Knives included: </strong>3-1/2 paring knife, 6-inch utility (or boning) knife, 8-inch bread knife, 8-inch chef's knife, 9-inch honing steel, pair of \"come-apart\" kitchen shears</li>\n   <li><strong>Block included: </strong>Yes</li>\n   <li><strong>Materials: </strong>High-carbon steel blades, POM (polyoxymethylene) handles</li>\n   <li><strong>Warranty:</strong> Limited lifetime against manufacturer defects</li>\n  </ul>\n </aside>\n <p><a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004U8QD9K/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&amp;tag=biipgf_092319_best-kitchen-knives-20&amp;camp=1789&amp;creative=9325&amp;linkCode=as2&amp;creativeASIN=B004U8QD9K&amp;linkId=df4280e6961992e84da48e7cc673d65a\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Wusthof's Classic Ikon seven-piece knife set</a> comes with a three-and-a-half-inch paring knife, a six-inch utility (or boning) knife, an eight-inch bread knife, an eight-inch chef's knife, a nine-inch honing steel, a pair of \"come-apart\" kitchen shears, and a 15-slot solid walnut block for countertop storage.&nbsp;</p>\n <p>This is the set for those who are building out a kitchen from absolute scratch and have a bit of money to do so. It covers just about every cutlery need, and should you decide to buy another knife for a highly specific task, there's plenty of room in that 15-slot block for extra additions.&nbsp;</p>\n <p>These knives are all forged (not stamped out) from high-carbon steel, which is fairly easy to sharpen, but also holds an edge far longer than the X50CrMoV15 steel found in many of the more affordable options we've tested.</p>\n <p>The handles are POM (polyoxymethylene), which has a smooth, satin finish. They're on the small side, but every-so-slightly ergonomically shaped, making them comfortable to grip.&nbsp;</p>\n <p>Some people may take issue with the serrated (or bread) knife, which, at eight inches, is a bit small. A 10 or 11-inch blade is preferable, especially when it comes to slicing a large peasant loaf, although a knife of that size won't easily fit in a storage block. Take Wusthof's serrated knife for what it is, or use it to slice meats and smaller loaves of bread and invest in a larger bread knife to store elsewhere in your kitchen.</p>\n <p>These knives come with a limited lifetime warranty, which protects only against manufacturing defects. We've used these knives for nearly a year, and they've held up through many mishaps. We're confident they can handle most anything your kitchen might throw at them.</p> The best knife set on a budget \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60302453bed5c50011a2baa3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Victorinox 4-Piece Fibrox Pro set\" height=\"900\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Owen Burke/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> \n <h3>The knives in <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004IEBTZ4/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&amp;tag=biipgf_121317_best-knife-sets-20&amp;camp=1789&amp;creative=9325&amp;linkCode=as2&amp;creativeASIN=B004IEBTZ4&amp;linkId=b1f1ed3ad86ad577bb7d56a0ab528ba6\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Victorinox's 4-Piece Fibrox Pro set</a> are lightweight, easy to sharpen, and resilient as can be.&nbsp;</h3>\n <p><strong>Pros: </strong>Resilient, good edge retention, easy to sharpen, comfortable handles</p>\n <p><strong>Cons: </strong>Not very well-balanced</p>\n <aside class=\"breakout-box headline-regular\">\n  <ul>\n   <li><strong>Knives included: </strong>4-inch paring knife, 6-inch utility (or boning) knife, 8-inch chef's knife, 10-1/4-inch bread knife</li>\n   <li><strong>Block included: </strong>No</li>\n   <li><strong>Materials: </strong>High-carbon steel blades, Victorinox's proprietary thermoplastic elastomers (TPE)</li>\n  </ul>\n </aside>\n <p><a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004IEBTZ4/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&amp;tag=biipgf_121317_best-knife-sets-20&amp;camp=1789&amp;creative=9325&amp;linkCode=as2&amp;creativeASIN=B004IEBTZ4&amp;linkId=b1f1ed3ad86ad577bb7d56a0ab528ba6\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Victorinox's four-piece Fibrox Pro knife set</a> comes with a four-inch paring knife, a six-inch utility (or boning) knife, an eight-inch chef's knife, and an eight-inch serrated (or bread) knife. These are, arguably, the only knives you will ever need, and Victorinox's versions are among the more resilient ones we've tested.</p>\n <p>The knives in the <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004IEBTZ4/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&amp;tag=biipgf_121317_best-knife-sets-20&amp;camp=1789&amp;creative=9325&amp;linkCode=as2&amp;creativeASIN=B004IEBTZ4&amp;linkId=b1f1ed3ad86ad577bb7d56a0ab528ba6\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Fibrox Pro set</a> are made of the very same high-carbon steel as many affordable to mid-range knives (X50CrMoV15), but Victorinox cuts some corners with a stamped blade (rather than an individually constructed one), a molded plastic handle, and no real flair. However, those are precisely the correct corners to cut; if you're on a budget, you definitely want to purchase a set of knives whose blade construction was the primary focus. Fancy handles are great, but not when they're attached to insufficient blades.</p>\n <p>If you're looking to keep costs to a minimum, if your kitchen is fairly minimalist, if you share a cooking space, or if you're looking to furnish a second home or rental, this is the knife set to purchase (and then never worry about). Even with heavy use, you'll be able to bring them back up to snuff in short order, and butchers like Pat LaFrieda and commercial kitchens all over the world stock a smattering of Victorinox's chef's knives, which is a testament to the brand's quality.</p>\n <p>Could you stand to add a few knives to your quiver after buying this pared-down set? Maybe, but you can still prepare just about anything with these four basic tools, and if you're trying to stick to a budget, less is more. You could find a 17-piece set for about the same price if you wanted to, but we've tried a handful of them over the years, and considering how little goes into each knife in such a set, you'd find yourself replacing them sooner than you would like.</p> The best knife set upgrade \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60302515623bd30012bcc4f8?format=jpeg\" alt=\"F.N. Sharp Three knife set\" height=\"900\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Owen Burke/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> \n <h3><a href=\"https://go.skimresources.com?id=35871X943606&amp;xs=1&amp;url=https%3A%2F%2Ffnsharp.com%2Fknife-collections%2F3-knife-set%2F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">F.N. Sharp knives</a> feature 67-layer Japanese Damascus steel and riveted epoxy and fiberglass handles, which we find fit most hands best.</h3>\n <p><strong>Pros: </strong>High-quality steel, great edge retention, exceptionally comfortable handles</p>\n <p><strong>Cons: </strong>A little difficult to sharpen yourself (but that's what the sharpening service is for)</p>\n <aside class=\"breakout-box headline-regular\">\n  <ul>\n   <li><strong>Knives included: </strong>3-1/2-inch paring knife, 6-inch Santoku, 8-inch chef's</li>\n   <li><strong>Block included: </strong>No (but available)</li>\n   <li><strong>Materials:&nbsp;</strong>67-layer Damascus steel blades, riveted G10 fiberglass and epoxy handles</li>\n  </ul>\n </aside>\n <p>A three-and-a-half-inch paring knife, a six-inch Santoku (or Santoku Bocho, which translates to \"three uses\": chopping, mincing, and dicing), and an eight-inch chef's knife make up this elegant, if pared-down, triage of knives. If your needs would be better suited by a six-piece set, which also includes a bread knife, a boning knife, and a utility knife, that's also available for $660.</p>\n <p>Apart from looking unbelievably cool thanks to the VG-10 steel patterned into the blade, these knives are the most balanced and solidly built of any we've tried. We also like that three \"sharpenings\" are included with the purchase of every set, which should get you through a year to a year-and-a-half of constant use.</p>\n <p>We put \"sharpenings\" in quotations because what the brand actually does — and this is pretty ingenious, we must say — is send you a replacement set of freshly sharpened knives in a box with a prepaid packaging slip into which you'll put your used, dulled knives for return. After the first three sharpenings, though, the cost is on you and it's admittedly steep: $60 for the three-knife set, $90 for the six-knife set, and $50 for a steak knife set. For comparison, most local services will charge you $2-$3 per inch of blade.</p>\n <h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/fn-sharp-knives-review\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><strong>Read our full review of F.N. Sharp knives</strong></a><strong>.</strong></h3> The best knife set with a sharpening subscription \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60302631623bd30012bcc509?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Knifey knife set\" height=\"900\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Owen Burke/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> \n <h3>For those that don't want to spend a ton of money on a knife set but know in full confidence they won't be sharpening their own knives, <a href=\"https://knifey.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Knifey</a> is the full-service knife set to meet their needs.</h3>\n <p><strong>Pros: </strong>Surprisingly affordable, exceptional handles</p>\n <p><strong>Cons: </strong>Very sharp for the type of steel, might need sharpening (service) sooner than others</p>\n <aside class=\"breakout-box headline-regular\">\n  <ul>\n   <li><strong>Knives included: </strong>3-piece: 4-inch paring, 8-inch serrated, 8-inch chef's; 5-piece also comes with a 5-inch utility and a 7-inch Santoku</li>\n   <li><strong>Block included: </strong>No</li>\n   <li><strong>Materials: </strong>High-carbon stainless-steel blades, G10 fiberglass handles</li>\n  </ul>\n </aside>\n <p>Knifey's Essential Three-Knife set comes with a three-inch paring knife, an eight-inch chef's knife, and an eight-inch serrated (or bread) knife, which is precisely everything most people will ever need in the way of kitchen cutlery, though the brand does offer a <a href=\"https://knifey.com/collections/all-our-plans/products/deluxe-5-knife-set\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">five-piece set</a> as well as a single <a href=\"https://knifey.com/collections/all-our-plans/products/single-chefs-knife\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">chef's knife</a>.</p>\n <p>Made with what has basically become the standard steel alloy (X50CrMoV15) within the $100-$200 market, Knifey's cutlery includes supremely comfortable G10 fiberglass handles, which offer heft and balance. The chef's and paring knives have a respectable 17-degree cutting angle, and we found that the blades fell right through vegetables similarly to the way the Wusthof Classic Ikon knives did, even before and after chopping on a glass cutting board 200 times.</p>\n <p>A lot of people will find Knifey's service irresistibly convenient, and considering the price (starting at about $140 per year with two annual sharpenings), it's not an unreasonable expenditure. Likewise, if you want to do your own sharpening, you can pay the one-time annual subscription fee, receive the knives, and keep them.</p>\n <p>Knifey's service works similarly, if not exactly like F.N. Sharp's above: receive your knives, run them through their paces until they're dull, and then let the brand know it's time. They'll rush a set of freshly sharpened knives over, then you place your dull knives in the empty box, slap on a prepaid shipping label, and carry on with your newly sharpened knives.&nbsp;</p>\n <p>Too many people neglect their knives, which only makes chopping and slicing more arduous — not to mention more treacherous. If you tend to let your knives get dull, Knifey's service could save you trouble, and maybe even a trip to the emergency room.</p> Methodology \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60302682bed5c50011a2bab7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Our Methodology Knife Sets\" height=\"900\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Owen Burke/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> \n <p>I've been using knives regularly — as most of us have — for the better part of my life, and on and off professionally. I relied on my own experience along with the unbiased and uninformed opinions of five others during testing.</p>\n <p>Ahead of testing, I got in touch with butcher and New York City meat purveyor Pat LaFrieda as well as Mike Tarkanian, a research affiliate and a senior lecturer at MIT's Department of Materials Science and Engineering (DMSE), to find out what their requisites are for great knives. Here's what we settled on taking into consideration:</p>\n <p><strong>Edge retention: </strong>Our knife-testing process involved slicing a few fresh tomatoes, taking note of the ease with which the chef knife from each set handled the task. After we had sufficient data, we took each chef's knife to a glass cutting board and ran it over the surface 200 times. Some knives held their edge, others not so much. We looked at the edges after running the knives and noted if there were any visible changes.&nbsp;</p>\n <p>We then returned to the tomatoes, cutting a few more and seeing how much resistance we felt compared with the performance of the knives straight out of the packaging. Knives that held their edges passed on to further rounds of consideration.</p>\n <p><strong>Alloy, and the HRC (hardness rating): </strong>We consulted several experts in the field, but the most informative source we encountered was <a href=\"mailto:tarky@mit.edu\">Michael J Tarkanian</a> , a professor of metallurgy at MIT. With his help, we were able to cut through the marketing and the scientific terminology behind different alloys and what allows a knife to retain an edge.</p>\n <p>We looked for a hardness rating of around 60 HRC, which offers great edge retention while still allowing for an edge of around 15 degrees (though up to 20 degrees, which is duller than 15, was still considered sufficient).</p>\n <p><strong>Ergonomics: </strong>For a knife to work well, you have to be able to hold it comfortably in your hand. We asked an array of people to pick up knives and decide which ones were the easiest to grip; across the board, they went for the ones with heavier, rounded, almost bulbous handles.&nbsp;</p>\n <p>Balance between the handle and the blade is also key. Pricier knives almost always offer better balance because that extra cost goes into using denser and often more desirable materials, like layered Damascus steel.&nbsp;</p>\n <p>A well-balanced knife with a good blade will cut through vegetables with minimal pressure, like our top pick from Wusthof. A not-so-well-balanced knife will take a little force to get started.</p> What else we tested and recommend \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60302741bed5c50011a2baba?format=jpeg\" alt=\"What else we tested Knife Sets\" height=\"900\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">Owen Burke/Insider</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> \n <p>We tested 11 knife sets in total; here are a few of the others that we also recommend:</p>\n <ul>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00004RFN0/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&amp;tag=biipgf_121317_[%E2%80%A6]eativeASIN=B00004RFN0&amp;linkId=3a776bb7d2e7e42187703d2360ef749c\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\"><strong>J.A. Henckels (Zwilling) Classic 7-Piece</strong></a><strong>: </strong>We enjoyed using these knives almost as much as we did the Wusthof Classic Ikon set, but the handles were a little awkward to hold, and the blades didn't retain their edges quite as well.</li>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/reviews/out?u=https%3A%2F%2Fmadeincookware.com%2Fproducts%2Fthe-knife-pair%3Fvariant%3D32764115877967\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\"><strong>Made-In</strong></a><strong>: </strong>These are good knives and made of the same material as most of the ones we tested (X50CrMoV15). But the handles are a little small and somewhat awkwardly shaped. Still, you won't get a bad set of knives from Made-In. We wish the brand still offered three- and five-piece sets, though, because we think the six-piece is overkill for most.</li>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/reviews/out?u=https%3A%2F%2Fmaterialkitchen.com%2Fproducts%2Fthe-trio-of-knives\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\"><strong>Material Trio of Knives</strong></a><strong>: </strong>These are very well-balanced knives and we love how sharp they are out of the box. The magnetic block is a little unwieldy, and we found that these blades dulled more than others during testing, but that may be due to their exceptional 13-degree edges. The <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/reviews/out?u=https%3A%2F%2Fmaterialkitchen.com%2Fproducts%2Fthe-good-shears\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">$35 Good Shears</a> are a worthy addition, too.</li>\n  <li><a href=\"https://misen.com/products/essentials-knife-set\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\"><strong>Misen Essential Knife Set</strong></a><strong>: </strong>Misen offers attractive three- and five-piece packages at a great price. The knives are nicely weighted, and the AUS-10 (and lower-grade AUS-8 on smaller knives) steel offers a sharper blade than the common X50CrMoV15 you'll find in mid-range knives. That being said, AUS-10 requires more care,&nbsp;since it's easier to stain and the edges are more brittle. If you don't mind a little maintenance, a Misen set is all you'll ever really need in the kitchen.</li>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/reviews/out?u=https%3A%2F%2Fcookpotluck.com%2Fproducts%2Fknife-set\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\"><strong>Potluck Knife Set</strong></a><strong>: </strong>Also punched out of the same alloy as most knives we tested, these are about as affordable as a decent set of knives gets. The blades outweigh the handles, but they held up in testing and if you're on a really tight budget, Potluck is a good choice.&nbsp;</li>\n  <li><a href=\"https://shun.kaiusa.com/sora-2-pc-chef-s-set.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\"><strong>Shun 2-Pc Chef's Set</strong></a><strong>: </strong>Shun is a favorite of some of the world's top chefs, and this is one of their more economical sets. If you're interested in Japanese blades but don't want to break the bank, these are a great start. They're extremely sharp at 14 degrees, but the edges are somewhat brittle and should be handled delicately and dried properly.</li>\n  <li><a href=\"https://shun.kaiusa.com/classic-2-pc-starter-set.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\"><strong>Shun 2-Pc Classic Set</strong></a><strong>: </strong>A step up from Shun's Chef's Set, these are beautiful knives that cut more smoothly than any we tested. A 16-degree one-sided edge isn't quite as sharp as some others you might find of this style (and price), but it does lend the blades some longevity. The 34-layer Damascus steel looks great and adds a lot of weight, and the offset handle fits nicely (if you're right-handed). This is a great upgrade pick for anyone specifically interested in Japanese knives, and we wholly recommend it as such.&nbsp;</li>\n </ul> What we look forward to testing \n <p>Here are some knife sets we're currently considering for future updates:</p>\n <ul>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.globalcutleryusa.com/classic-g2338\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\"><strong>Global Classic 3-Piece Knife Set</strong></a><strong>: </strong>This three-piece set, and the brand in general, is a favorite among chefs including the late Anthony Bourdain.</li>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.macknife.com/products/professional-series-set-3-pcs-pro-31\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\"><strong>MAC Professional Series 3-Piece Set</strong></a><strong>: </strong>Mac is another chef favorite, and this one is lauded as a workhorse by Eric Ripert, co-owner and executive chef of the thrice-Michelin-starred New York City fixture Le Bernardin. It's a little on the pricey side, but we're curious to see how it stacks up to our investment pick.</li>\n </ul> Why you may want to put your knife set together piecemeal \n <p>Depending on your budget, you may want to consider other options besides a knife set. Any time you're buying a set of something, the brand and/or manufacturer often adds in fillers (i.e. less than useful pieces) and cuts corners, and the case is no different with knives.</p>\n <p>A lot of chefs we spoke with recommend keeping only one, two, or maybe three knives in a kitchen: a chef's knife for most tasks, a paring knife for smaller jobs like peeling fruit or scoring dough, and a bread knife. You might also consider forgoing a knife block for a magnetic bar, which takes up far less space when stuck to the side of your fridge or mounted on a wall. Over time, you may want to add something like a utility or boning knife, but the truth is most kitchens will rarely find much use for one. If you do need one, you know who you are, and you probably carve a lot of poultry and/or meat.</p> Check out our other knife-related guides \n <figure> \n  <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5a009c7858a0c130008b6de0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"john boos\" height=\"605\" width=\"807\" charset=\"\"> \n   <figcaption> \n    <p class=\"copyright\">John Boos</p> \n   </figcaption> </img>\n </figure> \n <h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-kitchen-knives\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\">The best kitchen knives</a></h3>\n <hr />\n <h3><a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/best-cutting-board\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\">The best cutting boards</a></h3>\n <hr />\n <h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-knife-block\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\">The best knife blocks</a></h3> \n</div>\n<div class=\"read-original\">\n Read the original article on \n <a dn3@2020_6/2021/04/10/03-45-54-441_2216fa000f917b5d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/Zh6o_HAS4R0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn75@2020_4/2021/04/10/03-46-08-736_16374e7d9824f965.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1618026331630},{"createdTime":"2021-04-10 11:45:31","updatedTime":"2021-04-10 11:45:31","title":"Medical examiner says George Floyd's encounter with former police officer Derek Chauvin caused his death","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/medical-examiner-says-george-floyd-had-no-damage-to-heart-2021-4","description":"<figure> \n <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6070ac344943790018bb1b84?format=jpeg\" alt=\"AP21099686128462\" height=\"1250\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\"> \n  <figcaption>\n   In this image from video, Dr. Andrew Baker, Hennepin County Medical Examiner, testifies as Hennepin County Judge Peter Cahill presides Friday, April 9, 2021, in the trial of former Minneapolis police Officer Derek Chauvin at the Hennepin County Courthouse in Minneapolis, Minn. Chauvin is charged in the May 25, 2020 death of George Floyd. \n   <p class=\"copyright\">Court TV via AP, Pool</p> \n  </figcaption> </img>\n</figure>\n<ul class=\"summary-list\"> \n <li>George Floyd's health and drug use did not cause his death, a medical examiner testified Friday.</li> \n <li>His encounter with Derek Chauvin was \"just more than Mr. Floyd could take,\" Dr. Andrew Baker said.</li> \n <li>Chauvin has been charged with murder over Floyd's May 2020 death, which spurred nationwide protests.</li> \n <li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider's business page</a>.</li> \n</ul>\n<p>George Floyd was a healthy 46-year-old man before he died in 2020 during a police encounter in Minneapolis, according to the doctor who performed Floyd's autopsy. And while drug use and preexisting medical conditions may have contributed to his death, it was the encounter with law enforcement that caused it.</p>\n<p>\"To the best of my knowledge, he was generally healthy on May 25, before the events of that evening,\" Dr. Andrew Baker, Hennepin County Chief Medical Examiner, testified Friday during the murder trial of former police officer Derek Chauvin.</p>\n<p>Chauvin, who is white, was fired after video captured him placing his knee on Floyd's neck, an unarmed Black man, for more than nine minutes, despite pleas from Floyd and bystanders to stop. \"I can't breathe,\" Floyd said. He was later pronounced dead due to a lack of oxygen.</p>\n<p>The former Minneapolis cop is on trial for second-degree unintentional murder, third-degree murder, and second-degree manslaughter charges. His defense team has argued Chauvin was merely following department policy - a claim disputed by police - and that Floyd's drug use contributed to his death.</p>\n<p>During his autopsy, Baker said he did not discover any visible damage to Floyd's heart or brain. And while the examination did reveal that Floyd had COVID-19, it did not uncover any damage to his lungs that would suggest it contributed to his death.</p>\n<p>But Floyd did have heart disease and narrow coronary arteries, Baker testified.</p>\n<p>\"He already has a heart that needs more oxygen than a normal heart,\" he said. And a physical encounter with law enforcement is \"going to cause stress hormones to pour into your body,\" including adrenaline, which is \"going to ask your heart to beat faster, it's going to ask your body for more oxygen.\"</p>\n<p>Although use of drugs, such as Fentanyl, and preexisting medical conditions may have contributed to Floyd's death, Baker testified, it was not the cause.</p>\n<p>\"In my opinion, the law enforcement subdual, restraint, and neck compression was just more than Mr. Floyd could take, by virtue of those heart conditions,\" Baker said.</p>\n<p>Floyd's death spurred a summer of civil unrest, with Black Lives Matter protests across the US spurring new efforts to ensure accountability for police who abuse their power.</p>\n<p><em>Have a news tip? Email this reporter: <a href=\"mailto:cdavis@insider.com\">cdavis@insider.com</a></em></p>\n<div class=\"insider-raw-embed\">\n <iframe src=\"https://cdn.jwplayer.com/players/WBC5vSk2-gFnR6QwM.html\" 11:45:31","updatedTime":"2021-04-10 11:45:31","title":"The Republican National Committee is shelling out over $100,000 for a 400-person dinner at Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/rnc-spends-100k-on-a-400-person-dinner-at-trumps-mar-a-lago-resort-2021-4","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/607098074943790018bb1afe?format=jpeg\" alt=\"GettyImages trump mar a lago\" height=\"1500\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>President Trump&#39;s Mar-a-Lago.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Charles Trainor Jr./Miami Herald/Tribune News Service via Getty Images)</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The RNC is hosting a 400-person dinner at Trump&#39;s Mar-a-Lago resort on Saturday.</li>\n<li>The Washington Post reported that Trump has been hosting political events at his club.</li>\n<li> The move underscores Trump&#39;s ongoing influence within the GOP.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The Republican National Committee plans to throw a lavish 400-person dinner on Saturday at Mar-a-Lago, former President Donald Trump&#39;s Florida resort and residence, according to a <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-republicans-florida/2021/04/09/fb243b9c-9878-11eb-962b-78c1d8228819_story.html\">Washington Post report</a> published on Friday.</p><p>The banquet is set to cost more than $100,000, one person familiar with the event told The Post, and comes just two days after another dinner hosted by a conservative group with over 100 guests took place at the Palm Beach club.</p><p>On Friday, a fundraiser was held at Mar-a-Lago for Sen. Marco Rubio of Florida - the same day <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-04-09/trump-backs-rubio-s-senate-re-election-bid-after-mocking-him?utm_source=twitter&utm_campaign=C32D6E10-995A-11EB-ACB7-98F04F017A06&utm_medium=bgovium=bgov\">Trump endorsed his</a> reelection bid for 2022.</p><p>The back-to-back events are a sign of Trump&#39;s ongoing influence within the GOP as he continues to rake in money from Republican officials booking his properties for fundraisers and other political activities.</p><p>Also scheduled for this weekend are fundraisers for Trump&#39;s former White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders, who&#39;s running for governor in Arkansas, and GOP Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky.</p><p>The Post noted that at least six fundraisers for Republican candidates have been hosted at Trump&#39;s club since he left the White House, and that many more events are scheduled for this spring.</p><p>The RNC did not immediately return Insider&#39;s request for comment. The Post <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/rnc-holding-spring-retreat-at-mar-a-lago-after-trump-cease-and-desist-2021-3\">previously reported</a> in March about the RNC&#39;s plans to hold part of its spring retreat at Mar-a-Lago and to pay Trump for usage of the club.</p><p>The move demonstrates how many top Republicans still view Trump as a major figure in the party and believe his support matters for next year&#39;s midterm elections.</p><p>Though still banned from Twitter and Facebook, Trump weighs in on day-to-day political issues through statements released by his leadership political action committee, Save America. Besides Rubio&#39;s endorsement this week, he also <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/run-ron-run-trump-urges-sen-ron-johnson-to-seek-reelection-2021-4\">urged</a> GOP Sen. Ron Johnson of Wisconsin on Thursday to run for reelection in 2022.</p><p>Several high-profile Republicans have taken the trip to Palm Beach just to visit Trump, pose for a photo together, and talk to him about the party&#39;s priorities, The Post reported. </p><p>Trump spokesman Jason Miller told The Post that &#34;Mar-a-Lago and Palm Beach are the center of the Republican universe right now.&#34;</p><p>&#34;All Republican roads lead to Mar-a-Lago,&#34; Miller said. &#34;He&#39;s the biggest name in politics, and everybody wants his support and endorsement.&#34;</p><div 11:45:31","updatedTime":"2021-04-10 11:45:31","title":"Boeing's infamous 737 Max plane has a new issue, and 16 airlines are being told to ground planes","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/boeing-737-max-new-electrical-issue-southwest-american-airlines-2021-4","description":"<figure> \n <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fcfa9e3cee0cf00114fa202?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Boeing 737 Max\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\"> \n  <figcaption>\n   Boeing 737 Max aircraft of Alaska Airlines, Southwest Airlines, and Gol Linhas Aéreas. \n   <p class=\"copyright\">LINDSEY WASSON/Reuters</p> \n  </figcaption> </img>\n</figure>\n<ul class=\"summary-list\"> \n <li>Boeing's 737 Max, which was involved in two fatal crashes, has a new issue.</li> \n <li>Boeing said that some jets have \"a potential electrical issue\" and recommended they not be flown.</li> \n <li>At least 16 airlines are affected, including Southwest, United, and American.</li> \n <li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit the Business section of Insider for more stories</a>.</li> \n</ul>\n<p>Dozens of Boeing's <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/boeing-737-history-photos-airlines-2019-9\">737 Max plane</a>, which was involved in two fatal crashes, have another issue.</p>\n<p>The company <a href=\"https://boeing.mediaroom.com/news-releases-statements?item=130847\">said Friday</a> that some of the planes are facing \"a potential electrical issue.\" As a result, the plane-maker recommended 16 airlines immediately ground their affected models so that the issue can be resolved.</p>\n<p>\"We are working closely with the US Federal Aviation Administration on this production issue,\" Boeing said. \"We are also informing our customers of specific tail numbers affected and we will provide direction on appropriate corrective actions.\"</p>\n<p>Boeing did not specify which airlines or how many planes were affected, but Southwest Airlines, United, and American Airlines confirmed separately that they were. Southwest said 30 of its planes were affected. For American, it was 17, and 16 for United, the companies said.</p>\n<p>Sources briefed on the matter <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-boeing-737max-electrical-problem/boeing-flags-possible-production-issue-in-some-737-max-jets-to-customers-idUSKBN2BW1EE?il=0\">told Reuters</a> that 90 planes worldwide were affected. </p>\n<p>Boeing's 737 has been in production since the late '60s, but the most recent model - the 737 Max - has been notoriously problem-riddled. It was involved in two fatal crashes, with 346 fatalities, and was grounded worldwide for more than a year as Boeing worked with the Federal Aviation Administration and international regulators to sort out the plane's issues.</p>\n<p>It was <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/boeing-737-max-faa-approval-grounding-flights-safety-pilots-2020-11\">recertified for flight</a> in late 2020, and Boeing recently began delivering new models to waiting customers.</p>\n<p>Shares of Boeing fell slightly, about 1.4%, in early trading Friday following the announcement.</p>\n<p><em><strong>Got a tip?</strong> Contact Insider senior correspondent Ben Gilbert via email (<a href=\"mailto:bgilbert@insider.com\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\">bgilbert@insider.com</a>),</em><em> or Twitter DM (<a href=\"https://twitter.com/RealBenGilbert\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\">@realbengilbert</a>). We can keep sources anonymous. Use a nonwork device to reach out. upgrades","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-redeem-roblox-gift-card","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6070b9ed4943790018bb1bf0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Roblox\" height=\"1249\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>There are two ways you can redeem a Roblox gift card.\n<p class=\"copyright\">SOPA Images / Contributor / Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li aria-level=\"1\">You can redeem a Roblox gift card in a browser but not in the app.</li>\n<li aria-level=\"1\">You can redeem your gift card by applying the balance to your account, or by using it during the checkout process.</li>\n<li aria-level=\"1\">You may run into issues if your code includes a one or a zero; in that case, replace them with the letter &#34;I&#34; or &#34;O,&#34; respectively.</li>\n<li aria-level=\"1\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Visit Insider&#39;s Tech Reference library for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/roblox\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Roblox</a> contains a wide world of user-generated games, and while playing is free, in-game upgrades and avatar accessories (as well as a premium membership) will cost you. </p><p>But if you have a Roblox gift card, you can use that to pay for the platform&#39;s virtual currency, Robux, and take advantage of those extra options.</p><p>There are two ways to redeem a Roblox gift card: Applying the balance to your account or using it while checking out. Either way, you&#39;ll need to go through a web browser, because these processes are not available on the app.</p><aside class=\"breakout-box headline-regular\"><h2><strong>How to redeem a Roblox gift card by crediting your account</strong></h2><p>This should only take a minute or so to complete:<br><br></p><ol><li aria-level=\"1\">Go to the Roblox <a href=\"https://www.roblox.com/gamecards/redeem\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">gift card redemption page</a> in a web browser.</li><li aria-level=\"1\">Log into your account.</li><li aria-level=\"1\">Enter your gift card PIN and click &#34;Redeem.&#34;<br><br><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6070b49ca451820019b3a5f2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"How to redeem Roblox gift card 1\" height=\"1072\" width=\"1962\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Enter the code and hit &#34;Redeem.&#34;\n<p class=\"copyright\">Devon Delfino/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></li><li aria-level=\"1\">You should see a message saying you&#39;ve successfully had the credit applied to your account. But for those who have trouble and appear to have a one or zero in their gift card code, be aware that you may have to re-enter your code and replace those numbers with either a capital letter &#34;I&#34; or &#34;O.&#34;</li></ol></aside><aside class=\"breakout-box headline-regular\"><h2><strong>How to redeem a Roblox gift card during checkout</strong></h2><p>Once you&#39;ve decided what you want to buy on either the <a href=\"https://www.roblox.com/premium/membership\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Membership</a> or <a href=\"https://www.roblox.com/upgrades/robux\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Robux</a> page, here&#39;s how to use your Roblox gift card to make the purchase:</p><ol><li aria-level=\"1\">When you see the option to select a payment type, choose &#34;Redeem Roblox Card.&#34;<br><br><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6070b692a451820019b3a5fc?format=jpeg\" alt=\"How to redeem Roblox gift card 2\" height=\"1242\" width=\"2030\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Click the circle next to &#34;Redeem Roblox Card.&#34;\n<p class=\"copyright\">Devon Delfino/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></li><li aria-level=\"1\">Click &#34;Continue.&#34;</li><li aria-level=\"1\">Enter your gift card PIN and click &#34;Redeem.&#34;<br><br><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6070b7114943790018bb1bd3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"How to redeem Roblox gift card 3\" height=\"1270\" width=\"1970\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Enter the PIN and hit &#34;Redeem.&#34;\n<p class=\"copyright\">Devon Delfino/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></li><li aria-level=\"1\">When the balance updates, click &#34;Submit order.&#34;</li></ol><p><br>You&#39;ll see a confirmation page once you hit submit. Be aware that it may take a few minutes for the upgrades or changes you purchased to be applied to your account.</p></aside><bi-shortcode id=\"related-article-module-end-of-article\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/7P9bZCGYtBw\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 09 Apr 2021 20:53:38 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/6070b9a2a451820019b3a60f?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"ed68b3f1622897d81bed9858242252c0","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn59@2020_4/2021/04/10/03-45-53-598_f8062f9f93dfb400.webp","destWidth":2222,"destHeight":1666,"sourceBytes":141954,"destBytes":141954,"author":"insider@insider.com (Devon Delfino)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/6070b9ed4943790018bb1bf0?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn35@2020_1/2021/04/10/03-45-56-526_be91911f3acd3002.webp","https://i.insider.com/6070b49ca451820019b3a5f2?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn71@2020_4/2021/04/10/03-46-07-204_3fbaf069fdc30715.webp","https://i.insider.com/6070b692a451820019b3a5fc?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn40@2020_5/2021/04/10/03-46-01-795_1eaef21ff59e4860.webp","https://i.insider.com/6070b7114943790018bb1bd3?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn31@2020_3/2021/04/10/03-46-00-007_e42ed0f15cfe4a1b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn43@2020_5/2021/04/10/03-46-06-040_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=7P9bZCGYtBw:8pTeF8Fo-Cg:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn56@2020_3/2021/04/10/03-46-05-031_6c1797e2d1e1f1ac.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=7P9bZCGYtBw:8pTeF8Fo-Cg:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn95@2020_6/2021/04/10/03-45-59-508_c9e9c10e7967541e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn75@2020_6/2021/04/10/03-46-00-486_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=7P9bZCGYtBw:8pTeF8Fo-Cg:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn64@2020_3/2021/04/10/03-46-10-195_bdf61c7d7d276b33.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/7P9bZCGYtBw":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn99@2020_4/2021/04/10/03-46-02-328_415dae2243bec9bb.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1618026331709},{"createdTime":"2021-04-10 11:45:31","updatedTime":"2021-04-10 11:45:31","title":"Why electric planes haven't taken off yet","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/electric-planes-future-of-aviation-problems-regulations-2020-3","description":"<div style=\"position:relative; overflow:hidden; padding-bottom:56.25%\">\n<iframe src=\"https://cdn.jwplayer.com/players/TaTZxhEi-jZbcmOYf.html\" width=\"100%\" height=\"100%\" style=\"position:absolute;\" allow=\"fullscreen\"></iframe>\n</div><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Air travel is not good for the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/airlines-scramble-to-overcome-polluter-stigma-as-flight-shame-movement-grows-2019-6\">environment</a>.</li>\n<li>Business Insider spoke with four aerospace firms betting on electric planes as a solution.</li>\n<li>They all have their own version of electric aircraft, from <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/first-commercial-electric-plane-completes-test-flight-video-2019-12\">retrofitted</a> combustion planes to a new <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/eviation-targets-commuters-with-electric-plane-alice-2019-6\">electric plane</a> built from scratch.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p><em>Following is a transcript of the video.</em></p><p><strong>Narrator:</strong> What could a future with electric planes look like? $25 tickets, quieter airports, or even shorter runways. Companies have been betting on battery-powered planes for this cleaner future. But even though electric planes have been around since the 1970s, they haven&#39;t really taken off. So, what&#39;s keeping them grounded?</p><p>In the late 1800s, two French army officers experimented with electricity to propel an airship, but they ran into problems when the battery just couldn&#39;t hold enough energy. This would become a recurring problem for the next 100 years.</p><p>When nickel-cadmium batteries were invented, the first flight with an electric motor took off, but it only lasted less than 15 minutes.</p><p>Then, in the 1980s, lithium-ion batteries were invented. They could store more power than ever before, leading to planes like the Solar Impulse 2. Starting in 2015, the solar-powered aircraft spent 16 months flying around the world, except it flew at an average speed of 28 to 34 mph.</p><p>Solar Impulse 2 is part of a movement in recent years to develop alternative energies, especially when people and governments started realizing just how bad flying was for the environment. The aviation industry emitted about 1 billion tons CO2 in 2019. That&#39;s about 2.5% of global emissions. That might not sound like a lot, but it&#39;s almost as much as the entire continent of South America emits in a year.</p><p><strong>Kevin Noertker:</strong> We need to make changes to the industry, and electrification is one of the big trends which will hopefully reduce that burden.</p><p><strong>Narrator:</strong> Electric planes have been on people&#39;s mind for a while, but two big problems are keeping electric grounded. First, the technology&#39;s not quite ready.</p><p>When you&#39;re trying to get an electric plane off the ground, you want a battery that packs a lot of punch in a little package, but...</p><p><strong>Carolina Anderson:</strong> Batteries are not as efficient as gas, and they&#39;re probably not gonna be for a while.</p><p><strong>Narrator:</strong> A battery&#39;s efficiency, or ability to hold power, is measured in specific energy. Right now, even the best batteries have a specific energy of only 250 watt-hours per kilogram, but we have to get closer to 800 to really start flying, and that is still nothing compared to jet fuel&#39;s specific energy, which is nearly 12,000 watt-hours per kilogram.</p><p>Think about it like those computers from the &#39;80s. They were huge, but way less powerful than the sleek ones we have today. Right now, batteries are like those &#39;80s computers. They&#39;re not as powerful as they need to be, and they&#39;re not just big, they&#39;re also heavy.</p><p>So if you want to add more power to a plane, you need to get a bigger battery, and to get that plane airborne despite the weight, you&#39;ll need even bigger battery that&#39;s more powerful, but that means more weight. And then you&#39;ll need an even bigger battery to offset that weight. Oh, you get the point.</p><p>But even if engineers design a plane around the shortfalls in battery tech, they have to take on the industry&#39;s second hurdle, certification. In the US, that means getting permission from the Federal Aviation Administration to test and fly an electric plane. Companies have to prove every inch of their aircraft is safe, passing a series of tests, one of which is to make sure the battery cells won&#39;t catch fire.</p><p><strong>Roei Ganzarski:</strong> If something goes wrong, you can&#39;t stop. You can&#39;t pull to the side of the road. There&#39;s only one place for that airplane to go. And so the regulatory stringency is much higher, the requirements for reliability, redundancy, and safety are much higher for a good reason. You have no alternate.</p><p><strong>Narrator:</strong> The FAA amended its rules in 2016 to allow electric propulsion systems in airplanes built for up to 19 passengers. The real problem, though, is that certification, even with these amendments, takes years, so companies have gotten creative. They&#39;ve started to retrofit old planes to get certified quicker.</p><p><strong>Ganzarski:</strong> You&#39;re taking out the entire old, gas-guzzling, emission-creating engine and its fuel system, and replacing that space and weight with an electric propulsion system.</p><p><strong>Narrator:</strong> Retrofitting has happened in phases. The first phase was from Slovenian company Pipistrel. It created the world&#39;s first all-electric two-seater plane back in 2007 by putting an electric engine in a glider.</p><p><strong>Tine Tomažič:</strong> Gliders are safe to fly by definition, even without a functioning engine, so we were able to experiment without putting anybody at risk or do harm to anyone.</p><p><strong>Narrator:</strong> Today, those planes are used for pilot training.</p><p>The second phase: a hybrid. Los Angeles company Ampaire replaced one of the two engines in a 1973 Cessna with an electric one. Ampaire hopes to get its new plane, the Electric Eel, certified for commercial flights by 2021.</p><p>And, finally, over in Vancouver, electric-motor manufacturer MagniX and Vancouver-based airline Harbour Air flew a retrofitted 62-year-old plane. A 15-minute test flight in December 2019 made it the world&#39;s first all-electric commercial plane to fly. It proved that electric could actually take off. The two companies&#39; goal is now to electrify the rest of Harbour Air&#39;s fleet of more than 40 seaplanes and have it certified by the end of 2021.</p><p>So, retrofitting seems perfect. The problem, though, is that it limits you to what the plane structure is already built for, so if the original motor is, say, 1,000 pounds, and you remove it, then...</p><p><strong>Ganzarski:</strong> I only have 1,000 pounds to put back in, right? I can&#39;t make the total package heavier.</p><p><strong>Narrator:</strong> Electric motors are smaller and lighter than gas ones, but remember, those batteries are heavy.</p><p><strong>Ganzarski:</strong> So you lose range because batteries, for the same amount of power, are so much heavier than fuel.</p><p><strong>Narrator:</strong> So while Harbour Air and MagniX figured out the balance of weight in their plane, the range took a hit. Their electric plane can go over 100 miles, a little less than the distance from Seattle to Vancouver, but for electric planes to be successful long-term, they&#39;ll have to go farther.</p><p>Israeli company Eviation might have a solution. Instead of retrofitting an old plane, its engineers built a plane from scratch. The nine-seater plane, Alice, was designed around the battery to reduce weight.</p><p>Omer Bar-Yohay: That battery&#39;s literally all over the place. It&#39;s under the floor, it&#39;s in the wings, it&#39;s the fuselage in different locations.</p><p>Narrator: Alice, in theory, could fly up to 650 miles, roughly a flight from Las Vegas to Denver, but because it was built from the ground up, getting her certified is taking longer.</p><p>Bar-Yohay: We&#39;re very confident that we will be testing the plane in flight early 2020 and believe that from that point on the certification process will take about two years.</p><p>Narrator: Each electric plane in development is different, but they all have one thing in common: they&#39;re going after flights under 500 miles. And while it may not seem like an impressive distance, these short-range electric planes could solve a major problem in travel.</p><p>In 2018, a little less than half of all air tickets sold globally were for flights under 500 miles, but instead of using small, efficient planes designed for these shorter routes, we often use expensive airliners built to fly thousands of miles. These planes are most efficient if they&#39;re able to cruise for a long period of time, but on a flight that&#39;s 50 minutes, these planes go up, and they come right back down. Currently, a 109-mile flight from Los Angeles to San Diego emits about 110 pounds of CO2.</p><p>Bar-Yohay: For a technical-savvy person, that&#39;s an insanity, because we&#39;re using the wrong tools for the job.</p><p>Narrator: In the last four decades, flying regional with commercial jets got so expensive for airlines in the US, Europe, and Australia that they began stopping service to regional airports. Today, of the 20,000 FAA-approved runways in the US, only 2.5% are currently active.</p><p>The regional airports left are running at a loss or even going bankrupt, but electric planes could be a fix, and there&#39;s already an infrastructure for them. Omer says 11,000 of those 20,000 US runways could support an electric plane, which is a lot cheaper to operate. Alice could save about $800 per flight hour compared to a normal turboprop plane.</p><p>Noertker: It&#39;s a tenfold increase in the number of potential destinations, all the while not having the significant burdens on the communities of noise and pollution.</p><p>Narrator: As for the distant future, electric aviation could come in all kinds of forms. Uber is already working on an electrical vertical takeoff and landing vehicle, or eVTOL, that could pick you up right at your house and fly you to an airport. Even big players like Airbus, Boeing, and Rolls-Royce are betting on this future.</p><p>Tomažič: We set out on a journey that&#39;s akin to crawling, walking, running, leaping. We&#39;re now in the phase of walking. The running part will be the bigger electric airplanes flying longer distances, and the big leaps, coming in a decade or so, will be the eVTOL segment, which is vertical takeoff and landing electric-powered machines that effectively take off and land where we want them, bringing the airports to people.</p><p>Narrator: Everyone we talked to said that&#39;s still about 15 years off, and now that an electric plane has actually proven successful, those in the industry are hopeful that investment into battery development will start rolling in. Because to break out of that infinite power and weight loop we were talking about, we&#39;re gonna need more efficient batteries for electric planes to really take off.</p><p>Bar-Yohay: The question is, when does it make economic sense and who has the many billions it will take to bring a product like this to market in 15 years&#39; time? So, is it the future? Absolutely.</p><p><em>EDITOR&#39;S NOTE: This video was originally published in March 2020.</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a
